title: Industrial brick warehouse from the early 1900s hides a spectacular family home
text:
Advertisement

An old 1900s brick warehouse that used to be an art gallery has been transformed into a four-bedroom home complete with a stunning pool area and collector's garage.

While you wouldn't know it from the outside - this Sydney-based project completed by Ian Moore Architects is an entertainer's dream inside.

Guests are treated to a stunning courtyard pool, a modern and spacious sitting area and a fully operational 'lab' that sits in the lower half of the house as a work space for the scientist owners.

An old 1900s brick warehouse that used to be an art gallery has been transformed into a four-bedroom home complete with a laboratory and collector's garage

Positioned in the heart of Redfern and surrounded by other residential blocks, this finished product puts an importance on bringing light into the space while still respecting its heritage.

'There was a strong emphasis on maintaining an industrial feel to the conversion,' Ian Moore told De Zeen.

'The owners asked that there be no timber, marble or black finishes used in the new interiors.'

While you wouldn't know it from the outside - which resembles an industrial building - this Sydney-based project completed by Ian Moore Architects is an entertainer's dream inside

'There was a strong emphasis on maintaining an industrial feel to the conversion,' Ian Moore told De Zeen (the bathroom with intricate piping becomes a shower)

The house itself is split into two levels with the upper section housing the living spaces including a master bedroom and the ground floor containing the garage, laboratory (pictured) and ancillary spaces like a kitchen and dining area

So instead they painted the large timber roof trusses that were already there a shade of white and left them exposed, incorporating colour into the furniture instead.

The house itself is split into two levels with the upper section housing the living spaces including a master bedroom and the ground floor containing the garage, laboratory and ancillary spaces like a kitchen and dining area.

A section of the roof has been removed to create an outdoor terrace area that extends into a living space on the second floor.

Despite the seriousness of the indoor spaces there is a natural tranquillity of the landscape which makes it feel like a holiday home

You can swim in the courtyard pool (pictured), lounge in the comfortable sitting area or check out the fully operational lab that sits in the lower half of the house

The laboratory was a necessary addition to the home to help with research into equine genetics - part of the owner's job - and their classic cars are kept as a hobby in the extensive garage.

Despite the seriousness of the indoor spaces there is a natural tranquillity of the landscape which makes it feel like a holiday home.

While there are very few pieces of wildlife in the surrounding habitat potted trees are helping to bring life and greenery into the space, making the family want to cherish both the indoor and outdoor areas.
description: An old 1900s brick warehouse that used to be an art gallery has been transformed into a four-bedroom home complete with a laboratory and collector's garage.
authors: Matilda Rudd For Daily Mail Australia
